oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Restless Heart Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Restless Heart (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Restless Heart; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) "Big Dreams in a Small Town" is described by John Dittrich as a universal statement of people wanting more -- (00:39) Biff Collie introduces Dittrich and Larry Stewart of Restless Heart in a Music City Album Review radio spot -- (00:50) Dittrich tells of how the studio dictates when an album is to be released, and Stewart, Dittrich, and Collie discuss the pre-production behind Restless Heart's fourth studio album -- (02:45) "Say What's in Your Heart" is described by Stewart as an aggressive song with difficulties during recording -- (03:39) Dittrich describes how Stewart won the lead vocalist spot and Stewart describes Dittrich and Paul Gregg's vocal solos -- (04:42) Stewart remembers the moment, when driving, Restless Heart discovered "A Tender Life" and Dittrich describes the collective understanding, by the group, that "A Tender Life" would be their 'country standard' -- (05:55) Collie recalls a story of what causes a song to become great -- (06:07) Dittrich and Collie discuss the longevity of a 'standard' -- (06:56) Dittrich addresses every owner of a baseball team; Dittrich states that teams that have Restless Hearts perform have their team move on to the World Series -- (07:45) Dittrich describes the learning process of a musician -- (08:23) Collie questions the next steps after discovering a song, and Stewart addresses the desire to rehearse before performing it -- (09:11) Dittrich, Stewart, and Collie discuss the arrangement process when creating a song structure -- (10:16) Dittrich describes the advice given to him by Larry Londin -- (11:13) Dittrich jokes about the divorce behind "Jenny Come Back" -- (11:41) "No Way Out" is discussed by Dittrich, he describes it as the best vocal performance Restless Heart has performed -- (12:27) Dittrich and Stewart describe the gifts received from baseball teams and reflect on their ability to perform being directly correlated to the touring schedule -- (13:18) Collie infers about Restless Heart's huge popularity -- (13:32) "I'll Still be Loving You" is described by Dittrich as Restless Heart's career song -- (14:02) Collie questions the difficulty of working with others and Stewart and Dittrich describes the different bond of Restless Heart from other bands -- (15:46) "Why Does it Have to be Wrong or Right?" is discussed by Dittrich and Stewart as a rare cross-over from country music -- (16:22) "Big Dreams in a Small Town" is reflected on by Stewart as an extremely personal song for most of the members of Restless Heart -- (17:05) "Tender Lie" is said to be a 'staple' and 'classic' by Dittrich -- (17:24) Dittrich and Stewart describe the unknown possibilities of "No Way Out" -- (18:11) "Jenny Come Back" is described as an up-tempo 'fun' song by Dittrich -- (18:21) "Wheels" is reflected on as the song that had changed the career of the Restless Heart band; Collie, Stewart, and Dittrich reflect on the inspirational impact of "Wheels" -- (20:02) "That Rock Won't Roll" is described by Dittrich and Stewart as the song that 'got the ball rolling' -- (20:20) "The Bluest Eyes in Texas" is said to be a 'magical song' by Stewart -- (20:47) "Let the Heartache Ride," Restless Heart's first single, surprises Stewart and Dittrich for its continued popularity -- (21:53) Collie describes how Randy Travis released a track twice -- (22:08) Collie and Dittrich discuss the decision for naming the band -- (22:42) Dittrich describes the situation behind discovering "Calm Before the Song" while Dittrich was at Warner Brothers Studios
